abstract: The announcement by Nielsen/NetRatings to emphasize ranking Web sites by the time users spend may prompt a change in ad deals that may ultimately make for better Web sites. But it doesn’t mean that Google is down and AOL is up, as some have said.
snippet: The announcement by Nielsen/NetRatings to emphasize ranking Web sites by the time users spend may prompt a change in ad deals that may ultimately make for better Web sites. But it doesn’t mean that Google is down and AOL is up, as some have said.
lead_paragraph: One of the areas of the Internet that is widely misunderstood is Internet ratings. And that continues in the discussion of the change by Nielsen/NetRatings to emphasize ranking Web sites by the amount of time users spend on them instead of the number of separate Web pages they see.

headline.main: On the Web, Ratings Are Not Dollars
